did.unittitle: Schneider Collection

did.abstract: Focusing primarily on artifacts from the Barnum and Bailey Circus, the Schneider Collection contains material from the circus after the death of P.T. Barnum and into the 20th century. Photographs of the Barnum and Bailey Circus abroad also feature heavily, giving insight into what the shows were like.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Mr. Albert K. Schneider's family worked in the circus in the late 1890s and into the 1900s and beyond. His maternal grandfather William Strong painted signs, wagons, banners, and the like for the Barnum and Bailey Circus, and his step-grandfather, William Smith, worked as a veterinarian for Barnum and Bailey as well. As a result, Schneider grew up around circus people, and acquired a collection of circus material as he grew older.

Additional information about Schneider is limited, but he was involved with circus historians, as the notes regarding this acquisition mention a number of names active and involved with circus history during the 1980s. The collection was purchased from the Schneiders in 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Some time ago, the route books that were a part of this collection were separated out and are housed on their own.

The content of the collection is primarily souvenir material from various Barnum and Bailey Circus sojourns abroad. This includes various seasons spent in Britain, and the circus' time in Germany in 1900.
Of note, however, is the three-dimensional material. The material primarily relates to animal care, and includes files for claws and hooves, dentistry instruments, and horse related equipment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material has been grouped by circus and non-circus material, with the circus material coming first. It is then arranged by genre.

Three-dimensional items are held in two separate boxes. Most material is kept together due to size. However, the riding crops and scaler are housed separately, as the crops are made of bamboo and thus fragile, as well as the fact the items are long and thin, and thus need specialized housing.
